author: By Sam Roberts
title: Dr. Aaron Stern, Who Enforced the Movie Ratings Code, Dies at 96
description: He was a New York psychiatrist who went to Hollywood to help lay down guidelines for sex and violence in films. Not everyone was pleased.
content: Dr. Aaron Stern, a psychiatrist who as head of Hollywood’s movie rating board in the early 1970s established himself as filmgoers’ sentry against carnal imagery and violence, died on April 13 in Manhattan. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: A divided House votes to create a commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
description: The fate of the commission will be decided in the Senate, where at least 10 Republican votes are needed to pass it.
content: A sharply divided House voted on Wednesday to create an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol assault, overcoming opposition from Republicans determined to stop a high-profile accounting of the deadly pro-Trump riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Constant Méheut
title: Going Green, or Greenwashing? A Proposed Climate Law Divides France.
description: Emmanuel Macron’s credentials as a leader on climate issues are being tested as business and environmental groups spar over changes to the French way of life.
content: PARIS — Less meat in French cafeterias. Bans on short-distance flights.  Gas heaters on cafe terraces would be outlawed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ariel Dorfman
title: Progressives Won Chile’s Election. And They Won Big.
description: A new Constitution allowing for broad social and economic reform will be drafted to replace the one approved during the dark days of the Pinochet dictatorship.
content: Over the weekend, the people of Chile voted in a historic election to select the members of a body tasked with drafting a new Constitution to replace the one written in 1980 under the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Christiaan Mader
title: A Deluge Unleashes Floods in a Louisiana City Still Reeling From 2 Hurricanes
description: Lake Charles, which had been hit by Hurricanes Laura and Delta, has had some of the worst of recent storms that have dumped more than a foot of rain in Louisiana.
content: Slowly but surely, Lake Charles had been staggering back. In the city in southwest Louisiana, shingles had begun to take the place of blue tarps on more roofs. Signs and lampposts that were once twisted like paper clips had been replaced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Day 3: Try a Fierce Meditation
description: Day 3: Try a Fierce Meditation
content: We think of meditation as something to calm our minds, but did you know meditation can also make us stronger and more focused on the challenges ahead? Today, try a four-minute fierce meditation with the Rev. angel Kyodo williams, created just for the participants of the Fresh Start Challenge. Ms. williams, who capitalizes only her Buddhist name, Kyodo, teaches that fierce meditation is about showing up to whatever is happening in the world right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Paul Mooney, Trailblazing Comedian, Dies at 79
description: A comic writer and performer, he was known for his boundary-pushing routines about racism and social justice and for his work with Richard Pryor and Dave Chappelle.
content: Paul Mooney, the boundary-pushing comedian and comedy writer who made his views on race, racism and social justice abundantly clear as Richard Pryor’s longtime behind-the-scenes partner, a contributor to “In Living Color” and a performer and writer on “Chappelle’s Show,” died on Wednesday at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: JPMorgan Shakes Up the Race to Succeed Jamie Dimon
description: Marianne Lake and Jennifer Piepszak get new roles — and are potentially pitted against each other.
content: JPMorgan Chase announced a major management shuffle yesterday, renewing chatter about a hotly debated topic on Wall Street: Who will succeed Jamie Dimon as C.E.O.? The changes may also pave the way for a woman to lead the United States’ largest bank. Here’s the rundown:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: She Left Me There
description: Kacey Vu Shap spent 25 years trying to forget the Vietnamese orphanage of his childhood. Why did he go back?
content: Kacey Vu Shap had no desire to return to the Vietnamese orphanage of his youth. As a child, whenever he told people he was adopted, he would say that he came “premade” — that he spontaneously appeared one day at the Baltimore airport, greeted by a new family bearing flowers and kisses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Annie Karni
title: Publicly Supportive, Biden Is Said to Sharpen His Tone With Netanyahu in Private
description: Mr. Biden has spoken publicly about how he once sent Mr. Netanyahu a photograph with the inscription, “Bibi, I don’t agree with a damn thing you say, but I love you.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has maintained his public support toward Israel even as he adopted a somewhat sharper private tone with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, a calculus shaped by Mr. Biden’s longtime relationship with the Israeli leader as well as by growing hopes that Israel’s military operations against Hamas are nearing an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: A new coalition of 200 businesses will push fixes to the problems of child and elder care.
description: The council, led by the advocacy organization Time’s Up, includes heavyweight names like JPMorgan Chase, Spotify and McDonald’s.
content: JPMorgan Chase, Spotify, Uber, McDonald’s and almost 200 other businesses have formed a coalition focused on ensuring that women are not held back in the labor force because they bear the brunt of caregiving in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Lee Evans, Olympic Runner Who Protested Racism, Dies at 74
description: One of several Black athletes who had threatened to boycott the 1968 Summer Games, he won two gold medals, then raised his fist at the presentation ceremony.
content: Lee Evans, the Black American runner who won two gold medals at the racially charged 1968 Summer Olympic Games in Mexico City and at a presentation ceremony wore a Black Panther-style beret and raised his fist to protest racism in the United States, died on Wednesday. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Mob Violence Against Palestinians in Israel Is Fueled by Groups on WhatsApp
description: Israeli extremists have formed more than 100 new groups on the Facebook-owned encrypted messaging app in recent days to target attacks.
content: Last Wednesday, a message appeared in a new WhatsApp channel called “Death to the Arabs.” The message urged Israelis to join a mass street brawl against Palestinian citizens of Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, William K. Rashbaum and Ben Protess
title: New York’s Attorney General Joins Criminal Inquiry Into Trump Organization
description: The move increased the investigative muscle looking into the former president and his family business.
content: Donald J. Trump and his family came under increasing pressure from New York investigators after the attorney general’s office said Tuesday it was working alongside the Manhattan district attorney in an ongoing criminal fraud investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: My Patients Will Not Be the Same. None of Us Will.
description: The invisible scars of critical illness will be with us for some time.
content: As soon as I see the name on my phone, it all comes back to me.

title: The Meaning and History of a Controlled Burn
description: Wednesday: A small prescribed burn in Modoc County provided lessons on using good fires to fight bad ones.
content: Good morning.

title: India records the pandemic’s highest known daily death toll for a single country.
description: More than 4,500 people died of Covid-19 in India on Tuesday. The previous daily record was 4,468 in January in the United States.
content: India recorded 4,529 Covid-19 deaths on Tuesday, the pandemic’s highest single known daily death toll in any country so far, the authorities said on Wednesday, as the virus spread into the country’s vast hinterlands.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Introducing: Day X
description: A military officer, a faked refugee identity and an alleged far-right assassination plot intended to bring down the Federal Republic of Germany.
content: What starts with a mysterious gun in an airport bathroom and a fake refugee identity opens the door to a nationwide network of far-right extremists inside Germany’s military and police. It’s a story about a changing national identity — and the backlash against it — raising a question that democracies across the world are waking up to: What happens when the threat is coming from within?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: With restrictions lifting in France, Macron grabs a coffee at a cafe.
description: President Emmanuel Macron of France enjoyed an early-morning coffee with his prime minister at a cafe in Paris on Wednesday to celebrate the partial lifting of lockdown restrictions around the country.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France enjoyed an early-morning coffee with his prime minister at a cafe in Paris on Wednesday to celebrate the partial lifting of lockdown restrictions around the country.

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: A vaccine maker in India signals it won’t export doses before year’s end, slowing aid to the world’s poorest.
description: The Serum Institute of India said it would not be able to provide vaccines beyond India this year.
content: The vaccination woes of some of the world’s poorest nations will continue as the Serum Institute of India, a crucial manufacturing pillar in the plan to supply two billion doses of Covid-19 vaccines to low-income countries, signaled that it would not be able to provide vaccines beyond India before the year’s end.

title: The Guggenheim Is Proving That Museums Aren’t Just to Be Seen

content: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on reopening, reinvention and resilience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: Colorado Makes Doxxing Public Health Workers Illegal
description: The pandemic made health care workers a new target for having their personal information shared online, often with real-world consequences.
content: Colorado on Tuesday made it illegal to share the personal information of public health workers and their families online so that it can be used for purposes of harassment, responding to an increase in threats to such workers during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor and Amelia Nierenberg
title: What Will Camp Look Like This Summer?
description: Watch for social bubbles and shifting mask rules. And don’t forget the sunscreen.
content: After a year of isolation, many children are looking forward to summer camp with more than the usual excitement. Whether they have been stuck at home, blocked from recess or kept distant from friends, camp will offer a chance to escape their parents’ and teachers’ closer-than-usual supervision and connect with their peers.

title: Severe Drought, Worsened by Climate Change, Ravages the American West
description: Heat and shifting weather patterns have intensified wildfires and sharply reduced water supplies across the Southwest, the Pacific Coast and North Dakota.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — This year, New Mexican officials have a message for farmers who depend on irrigation water from the Rio Grande and other rivers: Unless you absolutely have to plant this year, don’t.

title: Subpoena to Twitter Is Said to Concern a Purported Threat to McConnell, Not Nunes
description: Details are trickling out about the Justice Department’s use of a grand jury to attempt to identify the user behind a parody account mocking Representative Devin Nunes.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump-era Justice Department’s attempt to identify the person behind a Twitter account devoted to mocking Representative Devin Nunes, Republican of California, stemmed from a U.S. Capitol Police investigation into a purported online threat to Senator Mitch McConnell, not to Mr. Nunes, according to two law enforcement officials.

title: Billy Porter Reveals He Has Been H.I.V. Positive for 14 Years
description: The actor told The Hollywood Reporter that he had feared disclosing it would give “another way for people to discriminate against me in an already discriminatory profession.”
content: The Tony and Emmy Award-winning actor Billy Porter disclosed in an interview with The Hollywood Reporter published on Wednesday that he learned he had H.I.V. in 2007 and hid the information from colleagues for over a decade, fearing discrimination in the entertainment industry.

title: New & Noteworthy, From Bob Dylan to the Bay Area
description: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: THE DOUBLE LIFE OF BOB DYLAN: A Restless, Hungry Feeling (1941-1966), by Clinton Heylin. (Little, Brown, $30.) Heylin, the author of “Bob Dylan: Behind the Shades,” revisits his subject’s early years with access to newly archived material.

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Pittsburgh Is Poised to Have Its First Black Mayor
description: Ed Gainey won the Democratic primary in a city that is roughly a quarter Black. The incumbent, Bill Peduto, is the first Pittsburgh mayor to lose a bid to stay in office since 1933.
content: PITTSBURGH — Ed Gainey, a five-term Pennsylvania state representative, is poised to become the first Black mayor of Pittsburgh, having won the Democratic primary on Tuesday night by defeating a two-term incumbent on a campaign of unequivocal progressivism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: The Case of the Disappearing Cicadas
description: The insect cohort known as Brood X may not emerge on Long Island, a sign of humanity’s effects on even nature’s most reliable periodic events.
content: On a bright day in July 1987, Elias Bonaros, then 15 years old, grabbed a bucket and headed from his home in Bayside, Queens, to Ronkonkoma, a town 40 miles to the east on Long Island. Dr. Bonaros — now a cardiologist, then a budding naturalist — wanted to see the huge, raucous group of periodical cicadas known as Brood X, which were due to come up in the town.

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Franco Battiato, Pop Singer and Versatile Composer, Dies at 76
description: Though hugely popular as a singer-songwriter in Italy, he never stopped experimenting. He composed for movies, opera and ballet, directed films and painted.
content: Franco Battiato, one of Italy’s most prominent singer-songwriters, who expressed esoteric ideas in catchy lyrics and, ever an eclectic artist, also composed operas and movie soundtracks, directed films and painted, died on Tuesday at his home in Milo, Sicily. He was 76.

title: Thousands of French Police Protest in Call for More Protection
description: The protesters declared that police work has become increasingly dangerous because of the government’s failure to fix the country’s social problems.
content: PARIS — Declaring that their work has become increasingly dangerous because of the government’s failure to address France’s underlying social problems, thousands of police officers protested in Paris on Wednesday in a show of force that left politicians scrambling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: McDonald’s shareholder meeting will feature a clash over board seats.
description: Ahead of the company’s annual meeting, some investors say they will vote against key directors, who are accused of flubbing the termination of the former chief executive, Steve Easterbrook.
content: Despite posting robust revenue and earnings during the pandemic of the past year, executives at McDonald’s are likely to face tough questions at Thursday’s annual shareholder meeting from critics who believed they mishandled the dismissal of the former chief executive Steve Easterbrook.

author: By Eric Kim
title: 18 Condiments Our Food Staff Would Lick Off a Spoon
description: The sauces, spices and pastes that bolster our everyday meals can be windows to the soul.
content: In 2018, the singer-songwriter John Prine told The Times that he would steal syrup, ketchup and mustard from the hotels he stayed at and keep them in his suitcase — “just in case of emergencies.” Here at the Food desk, we focus much of our time, energy and resources on recipes and the meals that grace our plates. But what about the condiments that bolster them? What would we steal from a hotel?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Ro, a health care start-up, will acquire Modern Fertility.
description: The parent of Roman, a digital health clinic for men, announced that it would acquire a firm that offers at-home fertility tests for women.
content: Ro, the parent company of Roman, the brand that is best known for delivering erectile dysfunction and hair loss medication to consumers, announced on Wednesday that it would acquire Modern Fertility, a start-up that offers at-home fertility tests for women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia, ‘Hermit Nation’? Some Warn Against Another Year of Shut Borders.

content: MELBOURNE, Australia — When Australian officials announced last week that the country was unlikely to fully reopen its borders until mid-2022 because of the coronavirus, the backlash immediately began building.

title: What Can and Can’t Be Learned From a Doctor in China Who Pioneered Masks
description: Dr. Wu Lien-Teh helped change the course of a plague epidemic in the early 20th century and promoted the use of masks as a public health tool.
content: In late 1910, a deadly plague started spreading in the northeast reaches of China, reaching the large city of Harbin. Tens of thousands of people coughed up blood; their skin pruned and turned purple. They all died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Back to Office at Saks Means Mandatory Vaccines, Optional Manicures
description: Marc Metrick, the company’s chief executive, says employees will have more flexibility but for reasons having to do with corporate culture, “the default needs to be our office.”
content: After more than a year of remote work, Marc Metrick, the chief executive of Saks, has a message for the company’s 500 corporate employees in New York: Starting in September, the office will again become the company’s primary workplace.

author: By J. David Goodman
title: U.S. Inquiry Into Cuomo Widens to Examine Virus Tests for ‘Specials’
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was already under fire after members of his family received expedited testing in the pandemic’s early weeks.
content: Federal prosecutors have been looking into whether Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration granted special access to rapid coronavirus test results for the governor’s family and other influential people, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Mike Trout Will Miss Six to Eight Weeks With Strained Calf
description: Trout has been having an M.V.P.-level season. Gleyber Torres was cleared to return to the Yankees and Kevin Pillar cheered the Mets from the dugout.
content: Mike Trout, the best player in baseball, will miss six to eight with a strained right calf, the Los Angeles Angels announced on Tuesday. Trout, 29, exited Monday’s game against Cleveland at Angel Stadium in Anaheim, Calif., in the first inning after grimacing while running the bases. He then limped down the dugout steps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: Their Fascination With ‘Real Housewives’ Is Anything but Fake
description: A cadre of Yale drama graduates have followed up a first streaming hit with “This American Wife,” a reality-blurring look at the long-running reality TV franchise.
content: Last fall, the theater company known as Fake Friends had one of the most attention-getting shows of the season, and not just because of its title. The troupe’s livestreamed production “Circle Jerk” was a viral hit, amassing Twitter love from Sarah Paulson, Roxane Gay and Hari Nef, and extending its run before briefly returning on demand in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Haigney
title: The Youth Prepare for #Summer2021, a Glorious Summer They’re Unlikely to Get
description: After a traumatic year, it’s hard to simply flip a switch toward fun. But have teenage summers ever lived up to expectations?
content: “All I want is THIS type of summer this year,” the caption reads, as a teenage girl on TikTok sways to the Kings of Leon song “Sex on Fire.” She covers her mouth like she’s about to happy-cry, and then the video cuts to a hyperfast montage of images, many inflected with a grainy, disposable-camera quality that suggests the past. I can make out: girls on bikes, sparklers at a bonfire, someone drinking wine from a bottle, a picnic blanket at a beach, the neon sign for a late-night diner, a red plastic Solo cup in someone’s hand, the trappings of a sleepover, someone dancing on a table, a rosebush in a rainstorm. It is over so quickly that it feels like one long, blurred vibe, nostalgia at high speed. “I think we all deserve it this year,” she writes, at the bottom of the video, along with #summer #summer2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Explore 100 Years of Immigration History With The Times Archive
description: In this lesson, students will use the New York Times archive to learn about immigration laws from 1882 to 1986. Then they will make connections to today.
content: This year marks the 100th anniversary of the first law passed in the United States to establish numerical limits on immigrants entering the country. However, the 1921 Emergency Quota Act was not the first time that the United States had introduced restrictive immigration laws. The 1882 Chinese Exclusion Act prohibited the entry of all laborers from China, and restrictive immigration laws would continue through the 19th and 20th centuries to today.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Three Inmates Killed in Less Than a Week in Alabama Prisons

title: Biden reappoints a top climate scientist who was removed by Trump.

title: Rennie Stennett, Pirate Who Had Seven Hits in a Game, Dies at 72
description: A second baseman, he was part of baseball’s first all-minority lineup in 1971, along with the future Hall of Famers Roberto Clemente and Willie Stargell.
content: Rennie Stennett, a former second baseman for the Pittsburgh Pirates who in 1975 became only the second major leaguer to get seven hits in a nine-inning game, died on Tuesday at his daughter’s home in Coconut Creek, Fla. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Zappa,’ ‘Trust Me’ and More Streaming Gems

content: This month’s curated picks from the back corners of the subscription streamers offer up a wide range of choices: unjustly forgotten star vehicles, clever genre subversions and a pair of first-rate music documentaries about very different artists.

title: Before Deadly Accident, Lift Boat Turned Toward Heavy Winds, N.T.S.B. Says
description: A preliminary report from the National Transportation Safety Board detailed the events that led to a commercial vessel’s capsizing off the Louisiana coast.
content: A commercial lift boat had begun to lower its legs onto the seafloor off the Louisiana coast during bad weather and a crew member had turned the vessel into heavy winds when it capsized last month, according to a preliminary report by the National Transportation Safety Board released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: As Restrictions Loosen, Families Travel Far and Spend Big
description: Newly vaccinated families are opting for private jets, luxury resorts and guided tours in elaborate new twists on the old-fashioned family reunion.
content: Jeff Belcher, 41, wouldn’t necessarily have chosen Williamsburg, Va., as the destination for his family’s first vacation since travel restrictions began to ease. But when his extended family decided to travel to the American Revolution-era town for a reunion this summer, he knew that he, his wife and their three children wouldn’t miss it.

title: Washington State Enacts Police Reform a Year After George Floyd’s Death
description: Gov. Jay Inslee signed 12 bills into law that include bans on chokeholds and no-knock warrants, making Washington the latest state to pass sweeping police reforms.
content: Washington became the latest state to enact sweeping police reforms in response to the police killing of George Floyd with the adoption this week of 12 new laws that ban chokeholds, require officers to announce their presence before raiding a home and call for the use of exhaustive de-escalation techniques before resorting to force.

content: If there was a single moment that captured the essence of Maya Wiley’s campaign for New York City mayor, the Women for Maya launch was it.

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Scarred but Resilient, New York City Tiptoes Toward Normalcy
description: The city reopened hesitantly, as New Yorkers balanced caution with a desire to embrace the freedom of prepandemic life.
content: From the Bronx to Staten Island, Chinatown to Fifth Avenue, in Michelin-starred restaurants and humble corner diners, hardware stores and funeral homes, New York moved gingerly toward reopening on Wednesday, with scenes of a remembered normalcy played out alongside those of caution.

author: By Kim Tingley
title: The Pandemic Was Bad for Our Teeth. Will It Change Oral Health Forever?
description: The rise of teledentistry and other alternatives have the potential to fix some of the disparities in care.
content: There are early indications that the pandemic is taking a serious, and potentially long-lasting, toll on our oral health. In September, even before the winter coronavirus surge in the United States, an American Dental Association survey found that more than half of the dentists who responded were seeing an increase in stress-related conditions among patients. These included teeth grinding, cracked and chipped teeth and symptoms of temporomandibular joint dysfunction, like jaw pain. More than a quarter of the dentists reported an increase in cavities and gum disease — quite likely a result of changes in people’s diets and hygiene. Americans have also had difficulty accessing dental care: A report last month by the CareQuest Institute for Oral Health, a nonprofit research and advocacy group, found that six million adults had lost their dental insurance because of the pandemic, and more than one in 10 had delayed getting care because of cost, lack of insurance, fear of exposure to the virus or a combination of those factors.
source.name: The New York Times

content: GAZA CITY — Riad Ishkontana had promised his children that their building on Al Wahida Street was safe, though for Zein, his 2-year-old son, the thunder of the airstrikes spoke louder than his reassurances.

title: ‘When You Hear the Heart, You Know It’s Your Motor’
description: Eduardo Rodriguez is the only major leaguer known to have developed myocarditis from Covid-19. The Boston Red Sox starter wants to keep it that way.
content: The bullpen session was supposed to last 30 pitches. Even after a nasty two-week bout of Covid-19, Eduardo Rodriguez thought he could make it through this ordinary baseball task last July. But by the fifth pitch, the top starting pitcher for the Boston Red Sox was so drained he said he was seeing stars.

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Did the Pandemic Change Summer Reading for Good? I Hope So.
description: With our calendars cleared last year, many of us found more time to lose ourselves in books. Let’s hold onto that vibe this year.
content: The summer of 2020 was a dud when it came to barbecues, vacations, family reunions, pedicures and swiping a lick from someone else’s ice cream cone. But there was one mainstay Covid couldn’t wreck: reading. For me, those empty, quiet nights were a reminder of the boredom that pushed me into the arms of books in the first place. They were also a much-needed reset on the high season of literary escape, which had become unnecessarily uncomplicated.

content: PHILADELPHIA — The overwhelming Democratic primary victory on Tuesday of Larry Krasner, the Philadelphia district attorney whose opponent tried to paint him as soft on crime, represented a major step forward for the growing progressive prosecutorial movement of which Mr. Krasner is a leader, advocates of criminal justice reform said.

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘King Richard’ Finds Fresh Drama in Watergate
description: Michael Dobbs’s new book mostly covers the first hundred days after Nixon’s second inauguration, when the president appeared triumphant.
content: Before delving into Michael Dobbs’s rich and kaleidoscopic new book about Richard Nixon and Watergate, it’s worth thinking a bit about the miniature kaleidoscope contained in its title. There is the literal meaning of “King Richard” — the fact that Nixon’s mother named him after Richard the Lionheart, the 12th-century English king who spent most of his 10-year reign waging crusades in the Holy Land. And then there are the Shakespearean Richards: Richard II, who was forced to abdicate the throne; and Richard III, the murderous tyrant. Dobbs’s title also happens to echo the title of “King Lear,” Shakespeare’s tragedy about a monarch whose need for flattery invites treachery, precipitating his own downfall.

content: Oak Bluffs is one of six towns on the island of Martha’s Vineyard. This three-season property is in the East Chop area, on a sliver of land between Vineyard Sound and Crystal Lake, on which it has almost 150 feet of frontage. Known as the Doll House because it is tiny, the main house is a converted early-20th-century fishing shack. It is half a mile west of the East Chop Lighthouse and a mile and a half northwest of the Flying Horses Carousel, which was acquired from Coney Island in 1884 and is the oldest platform carousel in the United States (and one of very few with a brass ring). The property is in a FEMA VE zone that requires flood insurance. The house has flooded more than once, most recently in 2018.
